page.title: 16Re-thatching Cottages
page.content: This year the two cottages adjacent to the Jackal public house in Thurleigh were rethatched. They are small cottages, but each roof took six weeks to complete and cost Â£5,000. The thatcher starts at the eaves laying the straw bundles side by side. As each bundle is secured on to the layer of old thatch it is secured by a hazel spar. They are then trimmed flat with shears. Each roof takes 2,000 spars, all of which are bent and twisted into shape by hand. The last stage is the ridge pattern, which is the hallmark of the master thatcher. On completion the roof is covered with netting to keep out birds and rodents. This is now made of plastic rather than wire netting. The roof can be expected to last some 30 to 40 years.
